But the japanese sub-titles ruin it.I thought that this was a hollywood movie not a foreign film.The dubbing from vhs to dvd is obvious and apparent I just wish there were no sub-titles in this American made film and the picture quality of the movie was a lot better. Title: N/A

reviewText: I will admit up front that I am a Cannon film aficionado. I grew up with and still adore all their 80s cheesy action offerings. Before their loveable Charles Bronson, Chuck Norris and "American Ninja" offerings, Cannon released their "Ninja" trilogy consisting of "Enter the Ninja", "Revenge of the Ninja" and "Ninja III: The Domination". MGM released "Revenge of the Ninja" on DVD ages ago and for many years I have been patiently waiting for them to unleash the other two entries in the series. "Enter the Ninja" finally got a DVD release, albeit on their crummy MOD (made-on-demand) DVD-R program, but the transfer was good and at least it has been made available to fans. Sadly "Ninja III" was nowhere on the horizon for even a MOD release until a little company called BonZai Media Corporation unleashed it on DVD under the radar.BonZai is a rather shady company and the legitimacy of their releases is frequently brought into question. Their transfers are hit an miss ranging from beautiful anamorphic widescreen to crummy VHS ports. Still their releases are silver pressed discs so all looks good on the surface. Sadly with "Ninja III" it's a VHS transfer. I've seen good VHS DVD transfers in my day but this is not even on par with many of Lionsgate's releases. This is a bad VHS transfer with digital compression blocks frequent throughout and extremely noticeable on large widescreen TVs. To top it off, the VHS that was used for the transfer is a Japanese tape and is complete with non-removable (or burned in) Japanese subtitles.If BonZai was going to source their transfer from a VHS then why didn't they just use an American tape? My VHS has much better picture quality and doesn't have the annoying Japanese subtitles to boot. For fans of the film the DVD is worth picking up to complete the trilogy on DVD but only for a cheap price. The picture quality is watchable, barely, but I will admit my personal transfer of the film to DVD-R from my old American MGM tape is far superior. Hey, on the bright side at least it's on DVD and it's even on a silver pressed disc, which is more than I can say for the MGM official DVD-R of "Enter the Ninja"
summary: Look at the bright side... at least "Ninja III" is on DVD

reviewText: The opening fight scene is legendary.  Golf ball crushing, eyeball stabbing, punching through the roof of a police car, ninja star to the face, this fight has it all!  The ninja even throws a star with his foot and shoots a dart down the barrel of a gun!A woman is possessed by an evil ninja who uses her body to avenge his death.  That's cool and the kill scenes are cool, especially the one at the cemetery, but unfortunately the woman also has a hairy boyfriend whose main habit is to show off the hair on his shoulders while talking a lot about nothing.Even with the hairy guy slowing down the pace NINJA III: THE DOMINATION manages to secure itself as a minor masterpiece in the ninja genre thanks to the martial arts skills of Sho Kosugi and David Chung.  Also look for James Hong in a minor role.You're not a true ninja fan until you've got this movie in your collection.
summary: Should be on DVD.

reviewText: First of all let me say, thank you Shout! Factory for releasing an excellent audio/visual presentation of this Cannon curio from the 80's, the kind of oddball in the Kusogi Ninja trilogy. While definitely not at the top of my list of favorite Cannon Ninja films, it's nice to see it given a proper release. That being said, being that there are more beloved Cannon/Firstenberg films that fans would like to see receive special editions, or at the very least standard Blu-ray/DVD releases, this release comes as somewhat of a mixed blessing.The real gem of this new release of Ninja III is the very well moderated commentary track by director Sam Firstenberg and stunt coordinator Steve Lambert. This is a commentary track that you can listen to more than once. Both key participants are very enthusiastic and have a lot of memories and details to share not only about this film, but about the entire series of Ninja films produced by Cannon in the 80's.Revenge of the Ninja, American Ninja 1-2 those are excellent films for what they were. American Ninja 3 and 4 and Enter the Ninja a little less so, but, nonetheless, entertaining and beloved films for the fans of the genre. (American Ninja 4 being a personal favorite of mine because it combined both Dudikoff and Bradley.) The film presented here, Ninja 3: The Domination, is, however, probably somewhere at the lower end of that list, just above American Ninja 5. It's great to have this film (the commentary makes it a buy and a really worthwhile experience), but at the same time it's sad that Revenge and the American Ninja films have not received the special edition treatment. It's especially sad that Avenging Force, which is possibly the best of all the Dudikoff/Firstenberg films, has been completed ignored on DVD and Blu-Ray in Region 1.So, this is a great presentation from Shout! Factory as per usual. Shout! Factory is awesome. Here's to hoping that Enter the Ninja, American Ninja 1-4, and the unrelated Avenging Force are given the same presentation eventually. In the meantime, fans of the Cannon Ninja series of films should definitely pick up Ninja III: The Domination, and, hopefully, in the future, we'll see releases of those other films as well.American NinjaAvenging Force [VHS]American Ninja 2: The Confrontation/American Ninja 3: Blood Hunt - 2 DVD Set (Amazon.com Exclusive)American Ninja 2: The Confrontation/American Ninja 3: Blood Hunt
summary: Fan Review of Shout! Factory's Ninja III Blu-ray/DVD

reviewText: In the city of Phoenix Arizona, a lovely aerobics instructor named Chrissy (Lucinda Dickey) was helping out with cable working until she runs across a dying ninja (David Chung) who was gunned down by a bunch of police officers and he dies as she takes his sword with him as a prized possession. It turns out she becomes possessed by the spirit of the ninja as strange things happen like her video game machine shoots lasers to the closet glowing as she starts to possess some of the ninja's abilities including the ability to crush pool balls to dust and assassinates some of the ninja's killers yet she struggles to keep her personality away from her officer boyfriend Billy (Jordan Bennet) but according to a legend, only a ninja can defeat another ninja so that the evil spirit can get out of the body for good and that is it as Yamata (Sho Kousagi) comes to aid the poor woman to do a martial arts exorcism on her.Part of Cannon's unrelated Ninja films that began with "Revenge of the Ninja" and "Enter The Ninja" as it's sort of an anthology of different themed films, this one is a departure from the formula yet still retains the action/martial arts formula fused with supernatural horror in it. Sure the acting is typical b-movie but the stunts and fighting sequences are super in this movie along with some cool special effects as this movie is like a fusion of The Exorcist, Poltergeist, Ninja Scroll and Flashdance with some jaw dropping sequences like a ninja who massacres a golf course and crushes a golf-ball to the scene where the ever hot Lucinda Dickey pours V8 juice on her body in a seduction scene. I always enjoyed this "WTF" film since i was a kid when i rented it on video and a nice enjoyable guilty pleasure in a MST3K kind of way, also look for James Hong (one of my favorite actors) in a role as a Japanese exorcist.This movie never had a DVD release over the years where the other 2 had but thanks to Scream/Shout Factory and MGM they FINALLY brought this overdue film for the first time on DVD and even better BD! Scream did a fantastic job with the HD transfer as it looks crisp/excellent and fantastic sound too with only 2 extras being photo gallery and audio commentary.
summary: A guilty pleasure FINALLY on blu-ray and dvd!

Title: N/A

reviewText: Ninja III: The Domination is one of the greatest so-bad-it's-great movies of all time. It's one of those films that will cause you to wonder (often out loud) to yourself how something this crazy and completely insane could get made. Well, thank the 80's for that!Technically the 3rd film in the Ninja series (following Enter the Ninja & Revenge of the Ninja), it actually has nothing at all to do with the 2 prior films other than featuring a ninja. The difference in this one is that the lead is a female played by the cute & very fit Lucinda Dickey (Breakin', Breakin' 2: Electric Boogaloo). Through a bunch of nonsensical plot events, she gets possessed and taken over by a rogue ninja after he is shot up by what seems to be the entire police department in the area that the movie takes place. The first act of the film in particular features one of my favorite sequences ever in a film in which the evil ninja attacks a bunch of people in broad daylight on a golf course. Hilarity ensues! Also, there's a notorious scene in which the lead actress who is a fitness guru pours V8 all over her neck & chest for her new male squeeze to lick off of her. You'll never look at vegetable juice again the same way!Unlike a lot of bad movies, this movie doesn't feature only one or two scenes to show people but much like other legendary bad movie fare like Troll 2, Samurai Cop, Megaforce, The Apple and Showgirls, Ninja III somehow manages to up the ante and craziness with each subsequent scene. The exorcism scene in particular makes me laugh out loud every time!The amazing folk at Shout Factory have rescued this title from VHS hell and given it a truly amazing HD makeover that is easily the best the film has looked since it was originally in theaters (in fact it might look even better than that). The film is showing in a 1.78:1 ratio (opened up a bit from its theatrical aspect ratio of 1.85:1) and fills up your entire HD TV screen without having to utilize the 16:9 option. Detail is truly extraordinary and none of the film grain has been stripped away so it retains a very nice filmic texture throughout. There's a tiny bit of black crush in some night/dark scenes but overall, Ninja III has never looked better. Prior to this blu-ray release, it was available on DVD only in a VHS transfer with burned in subtitles. I promise you that seeing this new blu-ray from Shout Factory is truly like seeing the film again for the very first time!The audio is presented in a 24 bit DTS-HD Master Audio stereo track and sounded great with audio being heard easily during some of the busier action scenes. There are no dubbed audio tracks and also no sub titles or closed captioning for the hearing impaired.There's only two extras on the blu-ray but they're a great ones. First, Director Sam Firstenberg and stun coordinator Steve Lambert through the assistance of a skilled moderator do a great job of talking about how they made this film as well as what it was like making low budget movies in the early to mid 80's. They realize how ridiculous the movie is but also take a great deal in pride in making such a great cult classic of B-movie cinema. The second extra is an extensive photo gallery showing Ninja III movie posters from all over the world in addition to production stills too.Finally, you also get a DVD copy too along with the blu-ray in case your kids want to get their Ninja III fix on the go in your van or something during the next family trip. ;)This blu-ray is a no brainer for fans of B-movies and 80's action cinema in particular. Shout Factory have once again knocked this one out of the park and have quickly turned into an even better version of what Anchor Bay used to be. Highly recommended!
summary: Ninja on a golf course! (and in glorious HD too finally!)

Title: N/A

reviewText: Ninja III: The Domination is a fun 80s popcorn flick made for sheer entertainment value, without any of the pretentious heirs of seriousness about it. On that end I completely loved this movie and usually put it on when I just want to be mindlessly entertained. People who write bad reviews based on a movie that sports a ninja spirit possessed aerobics instructor should not have watched this movie to begin with. 80s actress Lucinda Dickey, also known from Grease 2 and both Breakin' movies, plays the possessed character Christie who is made to avenge an evil ninja's death. As she finds herself blacking out often, only to awaken with strange cuts and bruises, she attempts to find out what is happening to her and why police officers are coming up dead. Fan favorite Sh Kosugi plays the good ninja who must save the possessed Dickey and battle the evil spirit to lay it to rest. The fighting sequences are very good as they go from fast and furious to slapstick depending on who is being fought. And while the acting isn't anything near Academy material, you still get a good feeling of each of the characters motivations. On a whole, the only words I can come up with for this movie are hokey, cheesy and all around good fun. So pop yourself some popcorn, open up a bottle of V8 and have yourself a good time.
summary: 80s Cheese At It's Best

reviewText: I had no clue about the ninja series and when someone reviewed it and said "It is like ninjas with flashdance meets poltergeist mixed in!"  Well count me in just out of curiosity.  This was the greatest film I have shown at horror night at my house next to Syngenor for comedy value. I have shown better films and I have shown some weird stuff here.  But this takes the cake.  I won't even tell you about the extras.  I haven't gotten into the extras but I wanted to slam a five star review up and then edit it once I get to it.  Scream Factory I have bought eight movies from now.  They have never failed to take their job seriously.  They take time to make the best cut of the film possible, to give you as many extras as possible and make it cost the same as a normal blu-ray film.  They love their craft and finding treasures like these used to be impossible but now with them I just wait for them to come out with a new film each month that I remember or like this I don't even know it!!!  They are that good at their job that they make me love movies I didn't know I ever would.
summary: Have a party and invite folks over and show this immediately!

reviewText: Like other reviewers I am a fan of the old 80s Canon films, but I have certain favorites that I've been gradually getting on DVD wherever I can find them.  I must say I was very pleased that Ninja III is available on Blu-ray and the quality is very good (at least as good as its original film... this is a bit like putting an old analog recording on DVD, you hear all the flaws because of the superior format).The commentary is also really interesting, you get to hear from the guy who did all the stunts and he's hilarious.  But I had forgotten just how awesome this movie is (yes it's a bit cheesy but that's part of the magic of many Canon films, stunts are done FOR REAL so maybe they "look" fake sometimes but it's better than doing everything with CG).  It does so great a job of capturing the atmosphere of the 80s, the women's workout clothing and some of the music and the hairstyles... And I always loved how this movie is more humorous than Revenge of the Ninja (Sho does many funny little gags).  Of course Lucinda Dickey, I mean wow she's hot.  But I had forgotten about all the Exorcist styled parts, and how hilarious all the Japanese spirit's taunting her in Japanese was.  Fantastic.I'm not particularly into movies that are "so bad they're good" ... but this is one of the best if that's what you want to enjoy it for.  If not, just enjoy the over the top Ninja sequences, plus some interesting drama and a really cool location (Tucson AZ).
summary: Ninja III - Excellent Blu Ray at last!

reviewText: If the cover and title perk your interest, this movie is probably for you.  The hottie on the cover gets possessed by a mighty lethal Ninja who finally, after an amazing amount of punishment gets killed in the opener.  A surprisingly good martial arts film, the director and stunt co-ordinator rely on no cgi--cause there wasn't any at this time folks--or trick photography, which would have been more likely.  Instead, this is just an array of stunt work at its finest and some older tricks of the trade.  The acting is actually pretty good and Shakespearean when compared to films of its time and niche.  Sho Kosugi however appears later in the story, and the real star is actress, Lucinda Dickey who convincingly plays a tough "lineman for the county," if you will, who finds herself in a most unwelcome situation.  There's definitely a feminist vibe to this one, and extra points for the unusual job, but woman power angle doest appear where you think.  The possession doesn't set Christie free.  She's already free, fit and secure.  The possession is the equivalent of a disease that she wants to be rid of.
summary: No, this is not something Meryl Streep would have starred in but as a martial arts/occult film it works out just fine.

reviewText: 1/3 Ninja film + 1/3 Poltergeist/Exorcist tale + 1/3 Flashdance = Great 80's Cannon Group / Golan-Globus film about a lady telephone lineman possessed by a Black Ninja. YOU CAN MAKE this stuff up.The commentary by the Director and Stunt Coordinator is very good. The director says "Poltergeist was HUGE, so you put some of that in with the Ninja angle.Filmed on locations in Phoenix. They even used the actual Phoenix Police Station (on a Sunday).Lucinda Dickey is HOT. She's also very athletic because she was a dancer. According to the commentary she did a lot of the stunts and fighting.  I saw this in the theater 3 times during the original theatrical run. I've been waiting YEARS for a DVD.My VHS copy was one of the FEW reasons to own a working VHS player.Now this is 'In the Collection'. I've seen it twice this week --- then added a 3rd viewing with the commentary ON.Thank You SHOUT! FACTORY
summary: Very Entertaining.  The 80's come alive! NINJA NINJA NINJA

reviewText: N3:TD (which has nothing to do with any of its Ninja movie predecessors) is a Ninja meets Exorcist mashup where an evil Ninja who cuts up a scientist and half the local police department for seemingly no reason at all transfers his soul into a spunky aerobics girl (Lucinda Dickey, va-va-voom!). Spunky girl at various moments gets possessed and dons Ninja suit to kill off the cops that shot down the evil Ninja. It's totally absurd and packed with all manner of 80's cheese. I saw this film more than a dozen times a kid, to the extent where the VHS rental guy began to hide the tape during my visit to the store. It doesn't hold up quite as well now, but is still good brainless fun.Scream Factory's transfer is quite amazing, from the perspective of a guy who had only seen the film in pan-n-scanned VHS form till now. Seeing it in the 16:9 ratio is quite a revelation. The DTS-HD MA 2.0 track is not going to win any awards for immersion, and the sound effects seem to be set a level higher than all the dialog and music, but this is quite likely the original mix for this low-budget exploitation flick and works. The disc has a commentary and a photo gallery for extras but inexplicably no scene selection menu. It would have been great if they could have interviewed Lucinda Dickey.
summary: Ninjas! Possessions! Aerobics!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ok ok let's go over the bad first. The picture quality is awful and the subtitles part definitely gets in the way. This movie has non removable Chinese subtitles and that can be a pain. However if you are like me (a nostalgia freak) and you must see this movie because of fun childhood memories then you should defently give a try. You could even enjoy it if you like cheesy 80s ninja movies. If you fail to follow any of the above then by all means stay away from this movie because you are not going to enjoy it. The story goes as follows:Ninja III starts off with an evil ninja assassinating a famous scientist and his wife for some unexplained reason (I was initially confused because the guy he assassinated looked nothing like a stereotypical 80's scientist). What follows is a 10 minute stretch of the ninja running from police, where the ninja kills roughly 40 - 50 officers. When they finally surround him after he takes out multiple police vehicles, including a helicopter, they shoot with him all manner of firearms - including revolvers, shotguns, and an SMG. He actually goes down 3 times and each time he gets surrounded by cops, and each time he gets back up and takes down about 6 cops before they can shoot the crap out of him some more - all just so the last time, he can throw down a little ninja smoke bomb and then disappear into thin air.Meanwhile, Christie (played by Lucinda Dickey - from Breaking' and Breaking' 2) - a local telephone technician - is hard at work when she notices a rustling in the bushes. She goes to investigate and finds a badly wounded ninja who tussles with her for a short time before somehow transferring his soul into her body through his sword. She reports the body of the dead ninja to the police, but doesn't remember finding him. Shortly afterward, she starts dating one of the police officers, and unluckily for him, every time she meets one of his police friends she has a flashback and the spirit takes over her body and plots its revenge.Thankfully, Yamada (Sh Kosugi) has just arrived from Japan, and he has a score to settle with this evil ninja spirit. He has to figure out a way to draw out the evil ninja spirit, and then fight it to the death in order to save Christie's life. The only problem is, the spirit may not want to leave her body and in that case, Yamada will have to kill her himself.Ninja III: The Domination is just plain 80's-tastic. From the aerobics and leotards to the music and the fashion, this is an awesome window into that time period. Like no other time, the 80's was the height of the ninja craze, and the notion that the Japanese assassin was an indestructible force that could take down 40 heavily armed men in the blink of an eye. To emphasize this, the first 10 minutes of Ninja III are the most awesome ass kicking ninja footage ever caught on film.While Ninja III can be a little ridiculous at times, it still is an extremely entertaining entry in the genre. You also may be asking yourself "Why is it called Ninja III: The Domination?"  Well, that's because it's a spiritual successor of sorts to Revenge of the Ninja and Enter the Ninja - except they don't really have anything to do with each other... None of the characters are the same, basically only Kosugi holds those three movies together.  Ninja III: The Domination gets 4 Shurikens  out of 5. Ha ha
summary: Good to see this classic again...but thge subs are a pain
Title: N/A

reviewText: 'Scream Factory' have done an amazing job releasing this mid 80's obscurity from 'Cannon Films'. The Blu-Ray transfer looks absolutely amazing and the sound quality is excellent as well. There is also an Audio Commentary track on the disc by director Sam Firstenberg and Stunt Coordinator Steve Lambert, which is one of the most interesting and comprehensive commentary tracks on film making. A very informative dissection of how an action film is constructed and made, as well as the amazing influence and input a stunt team has on the production of a film.I was left completely satisfied after viewing the film with the commentary track and it left me with an appreciation for the art of film making. I highly recommend this disc for the commentary track alone and hope that Scream Factory will release all their films with such great transfers and special features.I'd love for them to release 'American Ninja' on Blu-Ray in the near future, and in the mean time I will be exploring more of their great releases.Buy this and have a blast!
summary: The 'Scream Factory' release is superb! One of the best Blu-Ray releases ever!
